summary: This document is an internal email chain from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) discussing the coordination of Touhy requests related to Jeffrey Epstein. It focuses on managing FOIA requests from the New York Times and civil litigation discovery requests from alleged victims, establishing a point person for such requests, and outlining the legal procedures for disclosure.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney representing plaintiffs (alleged victims) in civil litigation related to Jeffrey Epstein. The email states she will be contacted regarding the procedures for making a Touhy request.

events.title: Answer Date for NYT FOIA Complaint
events.description: Deadline for the government to answer the New York Times's FOIA complaint challenging the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) response to records requests related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Coordination on Epstein Touhy Requests
events.description: Internal discussion to establish a point person within the U.S. Attorney's Office to handle Touhy requests from civil plaintiffs/victims related to Jeffrey Epstein, separating this from the criminal prosecution team.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA complaint challenging the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) response to its requests for Jeffrey Epstein-related records, with a government answer date of March 4, 2020.

The U.S. Attorney's Office established a protocol to have a designated Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) from the Civil Division act as the point of contact for Touhy requests from civil plaintiffs/victims, separating this function from the criminal AUSAs handling the prosecution.

The email includes detailed draft language explaining the Touhy regulations (28 C.F.R. §§ 16.21-16.29), which govern the disclosure of information or testimony from DOJ employees in third-party litigation, citing legal privileges like the law enforcement privilege.

Robbie Kaplan of Kaplan & Hecker is identified as counsel for plaintiffs (alleged victims) in civil litigation, who will be contacted regarding the procedure for making a Touhy request for government materials.
The correspondence highlights the office's anticipation of receiving additional information requests stemming from civil litigation by alleged victims against Jeffrey Epstein.
